channel.title: Spring JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [ROO-755] Exception using roo (Stack Trace + console locks up)
item.description:
Was trying out roo for first time, tried to move cursor back to change field name to add a similar field but roo threw a stack trace, and stopped responding.

Console output below.

hint interface jms logging metadata
perform persistence poll properties quit
reference script selenium system test
version web
~.domain.Horse roo> field number --fieldName height
field number --fieldName height
required --fieldName: The name of the field to add; no default value
~.domain.Horse roo> field number --fieldName height --type
field number --fieldName height --type
required --type: The Java type of the entity; no default value
~.domain.Horse roo> field number --fieldName height --type java.

java.lang.Integer java.lang.Long java.lang.Number

item.summary: Exception using roo (Stack Trace + console locks up)

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: ctrl-c, ctrl-q, ctrl-z, ctrl-x fail to kill roo and take me back to the windows command prompt.
This looks like a dupliate of ROO-69 to me. Can you confirm? The issue is that you cannot go back if the command spans two lines (an error caused by the external JLine dependency).
You are correct, it is the same issue. I am surprised that this is marked as resolved however. The end user will still consider this a roo bug regardless... oh well.
Duplicated by ROO-69
The problem is that JLine is an external dependency over which the Roo team has no control short of rewriting JLine.

Understood. I'm not saying that roo should fix it, just that it seems strange to close the issue.
When our customers find bugs with our software that are really bugs in the frameworks we selected they don't usually 'let us off the hook' for them. I've had to hack ibm jars hibernate etc. to resolve issues. At the end of the day we selected those frameworks.
I was looking through the unresolved defects to see what I could contribute back to roo a few weeks back, roo-69 wouldn't have shown up as something I could have looked into.
